body:
References: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32076#discussion_r1920491270, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13661T

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body:
drop this.

if vim has a different name for some minor feature it doesn't matter. we don't need to copy all their tags.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -844,6 +846,7 @@ Plugins:
 - tools/check_colors.vim
 - macros/{justify,matchit,shellmenu,swapmous}.vim: use `packadd! justify` etc.
   directly
+- package-helptoc. Use |gO| instead.

comment_data.body: textprops are a major subsystem, not merely a "compile time feature". I guess we can add a `Editor` section below (and move the cscope item into it, too, that doesn't need its own section)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -707,6 +708,7 @@ Commands:
 Compile-time features:
 - Emacs tags support
 - X11 integration (see |x11-selection|)
+- *textprop*. Use |extmark| instead.

comment_data.body: I doubt we will implement this interface, so it can go in the "Editor" section of `nvim-removed`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -662,6 +662,7 @@ These legacy Vim features are not yet implemented:
 - *'guitabtooltip'* *'gtt'*
 - *'mouseshape'* *'mouses'*
 - *'previewpopup'*
+- *popupwin*. You can use |api-floatwin| instead.

comment_data.body:
> if vim has a different name for some minor feature

Not only different name, it also use different command and interface. So unlike Nvim that uses `gO` mapping, Vim's helptoc package only uses the Ex command `:HelpToc`

Imagine that I am a Vim user converting to Nvim, to find the Nvim equivalent to Vim's `helptoc` package, I would mostly think of the keyword `toc` or `table-of-contents`. However, no helptags in Nvim matching those keywords lead to what I want, and also `vim_diff` has no entry matching it, so I think it is almost impossible for a Vim-to-Nvimmer to findout (by reading document only) that `gO` is what they are looking for.

Of course I already know that Nvim maintainers would not like a tag for `package-helptoc`, so I didn't make it a tag in the first place
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -844,6 +846,7 @@ Plugins:
 - tools/check_colors.vim
 - macros/{justify,matchit,shellmenu,swapmous}.vim: use `packadd! justify` etc.
   directly
+- package-helptoc. Use |gO| instead.

comment_data.body:
This should stay in some form.

> package.path and package.cpath are not really updated according to 'runtimepath', see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32478

The point is that things on 'rtp' are available to require(). That's a rather significant feature that is not (or was not) in vim. Being technically correct is less important than calling out useful concepts.

And I don't think this item is actually technically incorrect, the [semantics](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32478#issuecomment-2661585226) still apply. 

How about this wording:

```
- The require() search-path includes modules found on 'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -569,8 +569,6 @@ Lua interface (|lua.txt|):
   E5108: Lua: [string "<Vimscript compiled string>"]:1: TEST
 <  whereas Vim emits only "TEST".
 - Lua has direct access to Nvim |API| via `vim.api`.
-- Lua package.path and package.cpath are automatically updated according to
-  'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|

@@ -235,7 +235,6 @@ See also:
 • |builtin-functions|: alphabetic list of all Vimscript functions
 • |function-list|:     list of all Vimscript functions grouped by topic
 • |:runtime|:          run all Lua scripts matching a pattern in |'runtimepath'|
-• |package.path|:      list of all paths searched by `require()`

comment_data.body: Vim's `if_lua` also search for modules in `'runtimepath'`, so I think it should not be in `vim_diff.txt`. See https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/6098
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -569,8 +569,6 @@ Lua interface (|lua.txt|):
   E5108: Lua: [string "<Vimscript compiled string>"]:1: TEST
 <  whereas Vim emits only "TEST".
 - Lua has direct access to Nvim |API| via `vim.api`.
-- Lua package.path and package.cpath are automatically updated according to
-  'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|

comment_data.body: I have made that change to line 167
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -235,7 +235,6 @@ See also:
 • |builtin-functions|: alphabetic list of all Vimscript functions
 • |function-list|:     list of all Vimscript functions grouped by topic
 • |:runtime|:          run all Lua scripts matching a pattern in |'runtimepath'|
-• |package.path|:      list of all paths searched by `require()`

comment_data.body: then it should be mentioned in `nvim-upstreamed`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -569,8 +569,6 @@ Lua interface (|lua.txt|):
   E5108: Lua: [string "<Vimscript compiled string>"]:1: TEST
 <  whereas Vim emits only "TEST".
 - Lua has direct access to Nvim |API| via `vim.api`.
-- Lua package.path and package.cpath are automatically updated according to
-  'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|

comment_data.body:
Should it be like `if_lua: can require modules in lua/ directory in 'runtimepath'`? I don't want to mention `package.path` directly because it is a thing incompatible between Vim and Neovim

On the other hand, `vim.g, vim.w, vim.b, vim.t, vim.v, vim.fn, vim.call` are also Vim features ported from Neovim (though their behaviors are not fully compatible with Nvim). Should they be in `nvim-upstreamed` too?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -569,8 +569,6 @@ Lua interface (|lua.txt|):
   E5108: Lua: [string "<Vimscript compiled string>"]:1: TEST
 <  whereas Vim emits only "TEST".
 - Lua has direct access to Nvim |API| via `vim.api`.
-- Lua package.path and package.cpath are automatically updated according to
-  'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|

comment_data.body:
just paste this into nvim-upstreamed:

    - The require() search-path includes modules found on 'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|



> Should they be in `nvim-upstreamed` too?

idk, low priority atm.

 <  whereas Vim emits only "TEST".
 - Lua has direct access to Nvim |API| via `vim.api`.
-- Lua package.path and package.cpath are automatically updated according to
-  'runtimepath'. |lua-module-load|

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
- Lua: `require()` also searches for modules in 'runtimepath'.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -490,6 +490,8 @@ These Nvim features were later integrated into Vim.
 - |:sign-define| "numhl" argument
 - |:source| works with anonymous (no file) scripts
 - 'statusline' supports unlimited alignment sections
+- Lua: `require()` can search for modules in 'runtimepath'

comment_regular_data.body:
Backport failed for `release-0.11`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.11
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-34502-to-release-0.11 origin/release-0.11
cd .worktree/backport-34502-to-release-0.11
git switch --create backport-34502-to-release-0.11
git cherry-pick -x 8e17b720943e6f2240ddf5a52e65d6e7d841d61c
```
